content:
There are two issues here. First, there has long been an issue with setting the text colour in the message editor on macs, which is discussed here.

The second one is relatively new, related to the override setting in the Colours dialog (here). For some reason, this dialog is absent from TB 139 (see), although text colours appear here in the message editor and received messages with TB 128/139 on W11.

Maybe one of the tiny minority of mac users can offer more advice.
creator: sfhowes

content:
There is a workaround to fix this.

I finally went through the pain of downgrading back to something that did work, version 115. There I had the color button again and was able to figure out which config parameter that override controls. Prior to 128 you wanted it set to never. With 128, it changed it Only with High Contrast Themes.

The workaround is to go to the config editor (settings => General, scroll to the very bottom on the right side) in the search bar enter color_u and you'll get the parameter browser.display.document_color_use. The value will probably be 0. Click on the pencil and change it to 1. (in my case, when I typed in a 1, the 1 didn't show until I saved it, (click the check).

0 = Only with High Contrast Themes 1 = Never 2 = Always

I also found a bug for this https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1979848

content:
You asked in a different post about re-installing Thunderbird. The application and your data are stored separately. Re-installing Thunderbird will probably not help your problem. Re-installing should not affect your data. Making a back-up before any big operation is always a good idea anyway.

I do not know why you are not receiving messages. You will want to try some standard troubleshooting steps to help locate the source of the problem:

  1. Start your computer in safe mode.
  2. Open Thunderbird.
  3. In the "Help" menu, select "Troubleshoot mode..."
  4. Click on "Re-start".
  5. See if you can receive messages.
  6. Report findings here.
creator: mozilla98

content: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages
creator: mozilla98

content:
Check to see if Anti-virus is conflicting with Thunderbird. What Anti-Virus are you using ?

Either restart computer in 'Safe Mode with Networking' - you will need to connect computer to router using an ethernet cable as it will not operate using wireless connection. This is the ideal process as it will temporailly disable both default Anti-Virus and any you installed. Then start Thunderbird. If it starts up ok then you know it's probably the Anti-Virus.

OR uninstall / disable the Anti-Virus and then start Thunderbird.

You could also access Anti-Virus and set up an exclusion to not scan your profile folder. Then start Thunderbird and see if the pop up does not appear.

content:
Correct answer _________________________________ Thanks to Perplexity, but not ChatGPT _________________________________ The code that goes in [your profile folder]/Chrome/userChrome.css IS: __________________________________ /* Move the message pane to the middle in vertical layout (Thunderbird 128+) */ body.layout-vertical { 

 grid-template:    "folders folderPaneSplitter message messagePaneSplitter threads" auto /    minmax(auto, var(--folderPaneSplitter-width))    min-content    minmax(auto, var(--messagePaneSplitter-width))    min-content    minmax(auto, 1fr) !important;

}
creator: zens.info

content:
Can anyone help tweak this code? I need the splitter (messagePaneSplitter?) to go the other way

When I try to move the list of messages further to the right by grabbing the splitter and moving it to the right, it goes left, taking up more room (see pic). This is counter-intuitive and not like the old behaviour for this config-hack in previous Thunderbird versions.

________________________________________________________ For your convenience, here is the almost-successful code:

/* Move the message pane to the middle in vertical layout (Thunderbird 128+) */ body.layout-vertical { 

grid-template:   "folders folderPaneSplitter message messagePaneSplitter threads" auto /   minmax(auto, var(--folderPaneSplitter-width))   min-content   minmax(auto, var(--messagePaneSplitter-width))   min-content   minmax(auto, 1fr) !important;

}

creator: cboydg21

content:
You could insert a table just one cell width and as many rows as required for images. If you want to have text either side of image but with it's own right alignment then create eg: 3 cells width. You can set alignment of table itself as center using the 'Advanced Edit' button Attribute: align and Value: Center

Put an image in each row cell or middle cell if using 3 cell width. Set content alignment of a cell as center. Double click in the cell to get the pop up to set up cell properties. and set that cell to use alignment as center via 'Advanced Edit' button.

Now all text is normal and all images are central.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thank you, Your approach may be a good alternative but it's time consuming. Sometimes I spend 40 - 50 minutes recomposing some E-mails that are loaded with good pics that carry a decent message before I can send them off.
creator: cboydg21

content:
C. B. Gathwright said
Thank you, Your approach may be a good alternative but it's time consuming.

I'm not really sure whether you want to put text between images or you want to display a list of images with text before the first and after the last.

I just decided to test how long it takes me to set this up as to be honest I never really timed it before.

  • Press Enter a couple of times to give me some empty space at the top for text which I can insert later.
  • Insert > Table - create a table with 6 rows and three cells - that method allows me to put a small bit of text to the left of each image or I can leave empty.
  • Set up center on table using the Advanced Edit as previously described.
  • select each mid cell in turn - use Formatting bar to set Justify to center on all middle cells for each row OR do the double click and set up Advanced Edit - both work but Matt's suggestion to use the Formatting bar is probably quicker.
  • Insert > Image - 6 images which stored on my computer in my photos folder - one per line inserted into the mid cell and also set Image 'Dimensions' tab for each to 'Custom' and 'contrain' and set up width as 200 pixels - height is auto set.

It took just under five minutes. Now I just need to compose the text. So that's a reasonable amount of time. It would be quicker if I just added them as attachments, but that was not the purpose of this exercise.

Sometimes I spend 40 - 50 minutes recomposing some E-mails that are loaded with good pics that carry a decent message before I can send them off.

You mention 'good pics'..my images were my own personal photos, but some people do choose to copy images from websites. Please note - it's all too easy to think you are just copying an image, but you may also be inadvertantly copying all the remote content associated with that image. That means if the recipient has remote content disabled as is the default for security reasons, all those images will get blocked so cannot be seen. So please be careful about what you copy and paste when using other peoples images on websites.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Today I have found an answer after months of trying. Above the list of folders should be a cloud with a down arrow that is "Get Messages." To the cloud's right are three dots, which if clicked upon gives "Folder pane options." One of those options is "Hide local folders" Clicked on that to check it and then clicked on it again to unhide local folders. Voila, all my messages were back, even in my Sent folder. I have no idea why this would work, but it did.
